title: How to Make Strawberry Shortcake

steps.headline: Rinse 1 1/2 lbs (680.4 g) of strawberries in a colander under cold water.
steps.description: Use your fingers to rotate the strawberries until all of the dirt has been removed. Drain the water from the colander by gently shaking it over the sink. Then, pat the strawberries dry with a paper towel to remove any excess water. If your strawberries were pre-packaged in a container with holes, you can use that container instead of a colander to rinse the strawberries.

steps.headline: Use a knife to cut the strawberries into quarters and to remove the stems.
steps.description: Cut the strawberries on a cutting board to avoid scratching your countertop. Use the tip of a sharp knife to carve out the stem or to slice off the top of the strawberry. Then, carefully cut the strawberries into quarters—the pieces should roughly be about the same size. Pluck any leaves from the strawberries to make removing the stems easier.

steps.headline: Put the strawberries into a container with 3 tbsp (37.5 g) of granulated sugar.
steps.description: Use a spoon to stir the sugar in with the strawberries, and keep mixing until the strawberries are evenly coated with the sugar. The sugar will soften and sweeten the strawberries during the maceration process and will create a syrup out of the juices pulled from the strawberries. Freshen the strawberry mixture with 1 tsp (2 g) of orange or lemon zest for added flavor.

steps.headline: Seal the container with its lid and refrigerate it for at least 30 minutes.
steps.description: The longer the strawberries macerate, the more juice and syrup will develop. Just avoid macerating the strawberries longer than 2 hours as the fruit will begin to break down. Prepare the strawberries before mixing the rest of the shortcake to give them enough time to soak.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) before you begin making the batter.
steps.description: Remove any pans or baking sheets that you have in the oven before preheating it. Space the oven racks evenly within your oven, so you have room to place the 3 cake pans in it.

steps.headline: Mix together all of the dry ingredients in a medium-sized bowl.
steps.description: Start by adding 2 cups (240 g) all-purpose flour into the bowl. Then, stir in 2 tsp (8 g) baking powder and 1/2 tsp (2.6 g) salt. Continue mixing the dry ingredients until they are completely blended. To remove the lumps quickly, pour the ingredients through a sifter over the bowl.

steps.headline: Microwave 4 tbsp (56.72 g) of unsalted butter for 15 seconds to soften it.
steps.description: Place the butter in a microwave-safe container. Rest a lid on top of the container so it is cracked. This will keep pressure from building up in the container and allow the mixture to ventilate. Instead of microwaving the butter to soften it, you can also leave it out at room temperature for 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Use a hand mixer to cream the butter and sugar together in a bowl.
steps.description: Add 1 2/3 cups (333.3 g) granulated sugar into the large mixing bowl first. Then, use a rubber spatula to scrape the softened butter on top of the sugar. Slowly cream the two ingredients for about 30 seconds or until they form a yellow-white paste. If you do not have a hand mixer, you can use a standing mixer instead.

steps.headline: Add the vanilla extract, eggs, and milk to the creamed butter and sugar.
steps.description: Beat 1 US tbsp (15 mL) vanilla extract and 4 large eggs into the mixture first. This will help add air into the eggs and make your cake light and fluffy. Then, slowly pour in 1 cup (240 mL) of whole or 2% milk, and beat the mixture together until it is blended. For added flavor, you can also add in ⁄2  tsp (2.5 mL) of almond extract to the mixture as well.

steps.headline: Use a rubber spatula to fold the dry ingredients into the wet mixture.
steps.description: Continue mixing until most of the dry ingredients are moistened. Don't worry about blending the mixture completely because you will use the hand mixer to smooth the batter. This will prevent the dry ingredients from puffing upwards when you smooth the batter with the hand mixer or standing mixer.

steps.headline: Finish blending the batter until it is smooth using your hand mixer.
steps.description: Begin mixing it on the slowest speed, and then increase it to a medium speed to remove any lumps from the batter. Continue beating the batter until it is smooth. If the batter seems dry or crumbly, add 1  tsp (4.9 mL) of milk to moisten it. If the batter seems too wet or soupy, add 1 tsp (3.3 g) all-purpose flour to thicken it.

parts.name: Cooking and Cooling the Cake Layers

steps.headline: Put parchment paper on the bottom of 3 round 8 in (20 cm) cake pans.
steps.description: The parchment paper will make it easier to slide the thin cake layers out of the pan and will prevent the cake from sticking. The circles of parchment paper do not have to be perfectly round along the bottom but should cover the majority of the inside of the pan. Trace the circumference of the pan onto the parchment paper and cut it out with clean scissors or kitchen scissors to create a circle that will easily line the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Spray the inside of the pan with nonstick spray for extra protection.
steps.description: Pay special attention to the sides of the pan, as the cake will most likely stick to those instead of the lined bottom. You can also spray the pan before adding the parchment paper, and then spray the inside of the pan again to help keep the parchment paper in place when you pour the batter.

steps.headline: Spread 2 cups (470 mL) of the batter evenly into each of the pans.
steps.description: Use an offset spatula to push the batter until it covers the entire bottom of the pan. If the batter is not spread evenly, it may burn in thinner spots or be raw in thicker spots. Each cake pan should be filled with the same amount of batter so that all 3 layers will cook evenly. When cooked, the layers will be approximately 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) thick.

steps.headline: Bake the cake layers at 350 °F (177 °C) for 14-18 minutes.
steps.description: Distribute the 3 cake pans as needed to fit them into your oven. All 3 pans will most likely not fit on the middle rack so you will need to rotate the pans halfway through the baking time. This will ensure that all of the cakes cook and do not burn. When done, the tops of the cakes will be a golden color, and the centers will not be gooey if you test the center with a toothpick.

steps.headline: Use potholders to remove the pans from the oven and place them on a rack.
steps.description: Allow the cakes to cool for at least 30 minutes before removing them from the cake pans to cool the rest of the way. Once removed, let the cakes rest for at least 1 hour until the top and bottom of the cakes are cool to the touch. If you are having problems removing the cakes from the pans, use a knife or spatula to loosen the edges of the cake.

steps.headline: Whip heavy cream, sugar, and vanilla extract in a bowl for 1-2 minutes.
steps.description: Add 1 and ⁄2 cup (240 and 120 mL) of heavy cream to the bowl first. Then, sprinkle in 3 tbsp (37.5 g) of granulated sugar and 1 and ⁄2  tsp (4.9 and 2.5 mL) vanilla extract. Use a hand mixer or a standing mixer on a medium-high speed to whip the ingredients together. Continue to whip the mixture until it becomes fluffy and creates soft peaks. For added flavor, add in 1 tsp (5 g) of lemon zest before whipping the mixture together. You can also make a thicker whipped cream by adding in 8 ounces (240 g) of cream cheese to the mixture before whipping. This is a fun twist on the traditional whipped topping and provides extra mouthfeel in each bite.

steps.headline: Rest 1 cake layer on a serving plate you can easily transport.
steps.description: Choose a sturdy serving plate that will withstand the weight of the layered cake once it is assembled. A serving plate with a slight well to it will also help to contain the juices from the macerated strawberries.

steps.headline: Add a layer of whipped cream and 1 cup (240 mL) of macerated strawberries.
steps.description: Spread the layer of whipped cream thin so it does not pool out the sides when topped with a second cake layer. Then, carefully distribute the macerated strawberries on top without disturbing the layer of whipped cream. Don't worry if some of the juice from the strawberries runs down the sides of the cake. It will add to the presentation of the dessert and the cake will soak up the juices.

steps.headline: Place the second cake layer, carefully, on top of the first.
steps.description: Lower the second cake layer as close to the first as possible to avoid disturbing the fillings. If it helps, lift the second layer with a spatula, and push it off the spatula with your fingers and onto the bottom layer. Repeat the filling process for the second and third cake layer.

steps.headline: Garnish the cake with whipped cream, strawberries, or powdered sugar.
steps.description: Frost the outside of the cake with leftover whipped cream or leave the layers exposed to show off your hard work. Then, arrange whole strawberries along the top of the cake and sprinkle them with powdered sugar. Serve the cake immediately or allow it to firm up in the refrigerator for 10-15 minutes. Store any leftovers in a sealed container in the refrigerator for 5-7 days. Just be aware that the whipped cream may begin to separate after a day or so and become watery.

steps.headline: Finished.

text: Macerating the Strawberries Rinse 1 1/2 lbs (680.4 g) of strawberries in a colander under cold water. Use your fingers to rotate the strawberries until all of the dirt has been removed. Drain the water from the colander by gently shaking it over the sink. Then, pat the strawberries dry with a paper towel to remove any excess water. If your strawberries were pre-packaged in a container with holes, you can use that container instead of a colander to rinse the strawberries. Use a knife to cut the strawberries into quarters and to remove the stems. Cut the strawberries on a cutting board to avoid scratching your countertop. Use the tip of a sharp knife to carve out the stem or to slice off the top of the strawberry. Then, carefully cut the strawberries into quarters—the pieces should roughly be about the same size. Pluck any leaves from the strawberries to make removing the stems easier. Put the strawberries into a container with 3 tbsp (37.5 g) of granulated sugar. Use a spoon to stir the sugar in with the strawberries, and keep mixing until the strawberries are evenly coated with the sugar. The sugar will soften and sweeten the strawberries during the maceration process and will create a syrup out of the juices pulled from the strawberries. Freshen the strawberry mixture with 1 tsp (2 g) of orange or lemon zest for added flavor. Seal the container with its lid and refrigerate it for at least 30 minutes. The longer the strawberries macerate, the more juice and syrup will develop. Just avoid macerating the strawberries longer than 2 hours as the fruit will begin to break down. Prepare the strawberries before mixing the rest of the shortcake to give them enough time to soak. Mixing the Cake Batter Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) before you begin making the batter. Remove any pans or baking sheets that you have in the oven before preheating it. Space the oven racks evenly within your oven, so you have room to place the 3 cake pans in it. Mix together all of the dry ingredients in a medium-sized bowl. Start by adding 2 cups (240 g) all-purpose flour into the bowl. Then, stir in 2 tsp (8 g) baking powder and 1/2 tsp (2.6 g) salt. Continue mixing the dry ingredients until they are completely blended. To remove the lumps quickly, pour the ingredients through a sifter over the bowl. Microwave 4 tbsp (56.72 g) of unsalted butter for 15 seconds to soften it. Place the butter in a microwave-safe container. Rest a lid on top of the container so it is cracked. This will keep pressure from building up in the container and allow the mixture to ventilate. Instead of microwaving the butter to soften it, you can also leave it out at room temperature for 30 minutes. Use a hand mixer to cream the butter and sugar together in a bowl. Add 1 2/3 cups (333.3 g) granulated sugar into the large mixing bowl first. Then, use a rubber spatula to scrape the softened butter on top of the sugar. Slowly cream the two ingredients for about 30 seconds or until they form a yellow-white paste. If you do not have a hand mixer, you can use a standing mixer instead. Add the vanilla extract, eggs, and milk to the creamed butter and sugar. Beat 1 US tbsp (15 mL) vanilla extract and 4 large eggs into the mixture first. This will help add air into the eggs and make your cake light and fluffy. Then, slowly pour in 1 cup (240 mL) of whole or 2% milk, and beat the mixture together until it is blended. For added flavor, you can also add in ⁄2  tsp (2.5 mL) of almond extract to the mixture as well. Use a rubber spatula to fold the dry ingredients into the wet mixture. Continue mixing until most of the dry ingredients are moistened. Don't worry about blending the mixture completely because you will use the hand mixer to smooth the batter. This will prevent the dry ingredients from puffing upwards when you smooth the batter with the hand mixer or standing mixer. Finish blending the batter until it is smooth using your hand mixer. Begin mixing it on the slowest speed, and then increase it to a medium speed to remove any lumps from the batter. Continue beating the batter until it is smooth. If the batter seems dry or crumbly, add 1  tsp (4.9 mL) of milk to moisten it. If the batter seems too wet or soupy, add 1 tsp (3.3 g) all-purpose flour to thicken it. Cooking and Cooling the Cake Layers Put parchment paper on the bottom of 3 round 8 in (20 cm) cake pans. The parchment paper will make it easier to slide the thin cake layers out of the pan and will prevent the cake from sticking. The circles of parchment paper do not have to be perfectly round along the bottom but should cover the majority of the inside of the pan. Trace the circumference of the pan onto the parchment paper and cut it out with clean scissors or kitchen scissors to create a circle that will easily line the bottom of the pan. Spray the inside of the pan with nonstick spray for extra protection. Pay special attention to the sides of the pan, as the cake will most likely stick to those instead of the lined bottom. You can also spray the pan before adding the parchment paper, and then spray the inside of the pan again to help keep the parchment paper in place when you pour the batter. Spread 2 cups (470 mL) of the batter evenly into each of the pans. Use an offset spatula to push the batter until it covers the entire bottom of the pan. If the batter is not spread evenly, it may burn in thinner spots or be raw in thicker spots. Each cake pan should be filled with the same amount of batter so that all 3 layers will cook evenly. When cooked, the layers will be approximately 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) thick. Bake the cake layers at 350 °F (177 °C) for 14-18 minutes. Distribute the 3 cake pans as needed to fit them into your oven. All 3 pans will most likely not fit on the middle rack so you will need to rotate the pans halfway through the baking time. This will ensure that all of the cakes cook and do not burn. When done, the tops of the cakes will be a golden color, and the centers will not be gooey if you test the center with a toothpick. Use potholders to remove the pans from the oven and place them on a rack. Allow the cakes to cool for at least 30 minutes before removing them from the cake pans to cool the rest of the way. Once removed, let the cakes rest for at least 1 hour until the top and bottom of the cakes are cool to the touch. If you are having problems removing the cakes from the pans, use a knife or spatula to loosen the edges of the cake. Assembling the Shortcake Whip heavy cream, sugar, and vanilla extract in a bowl for 1-2 minutes. Add 1 and ⁄2 cup (240 and 120 mL) of heavy cream to the bowl first. Then, sprinkle in 3 tbsp (37.5 g) of granulated sugar and 1 and ⁄2  tsp (4.9 and 2.5 mL) vanilla extract. Use a hand mixer or a standing mixer on a medium-high speed to whip the ingredients together. Continue to whip the mixture until it becomes fluffy and creates soft peaks. For added flavor, add in 1 tsp (5 g) of lemon zest before whipping the mixture together. You can also make a thicker whipped cream by adding in 8 ounces (240 g) of cream cheese to the mixture before whipping. This is a fun twist on the traditional whipped topping and provides extra mouthfeel in each bite. Rest 1 cake layer on a serving plate you can easily transport. Choose a sturdy serving plate that will withstand the weight of the layered cake once it is assembled. A serving plate with a slight well to it will also help to contain the juices from the macerated strawberries. Add a layer of whipped cream and 1 cup (240 mL) of macerated strawberries. Spread the layer of whipped cream thin so it does not pool out the sides when topped with a second cake layer. Then, carefully distribute the macerated strawberries on top without disturbing the layer of whipped cream. Don't worry if some of the juice from the strawberries runs down the sides of the cake. It will add to the presentation of the dessert and the cake will soak up the juices. Place the second cake layer, carefully, on top of the first. Lower the second cake layer as close to the first as possible to avoid disturbing the fillings. If it helps, lift the second layer with a spatula, and push it off the spatula with your fingers and onto the bottom layer. Repeat the filling process for the second and third cake layer. Garnish the cake with whipped cream, strawberries, or powdered sugar. Frost the outside of the cake with leftover whipped cream or leave the layers exposed to show off your hard work. Then, arrange whole strawberries along the top of the cake and sprinkle them with powdered sugar. Serve the cake immediately or allow it to firm up in the refrigerator for 10-15 minutes. Store any leftovers in a sealed container in the refrigerator for 5-7 days. Just be aware that the whipped cream may begin to separate after a day or so and become watery. Finished.
sentences: Macerating the Strawberries Rinse 1 1/2 lbs (680.4 g) of strawberries in a colander under cold water.
Use your fingers to rotate the strawberries until all of the dirt has been removed.
Drain the water from the colander by gently shaking it over the sink.
Then, pat the strawberries dry with a paper towel to remove any excess water.
If your strawberries were pre-packaged in a container with holes, you can use that container instead of a colander to rinse the strawberries.
Use a knife to cut the strawberries into quarters and to remove the stems.
Cut the strawberries on a cutting board to avoid scratching your countertop.
Use the tip of a sharp knife to carve out the stem or to slice off the top of the strawberry.
Then, carefully cut the strawberries into quarters—the pieces should roughly be about the same size.
Pluck any leaves from the strawberries to make removing the stems easier.
Put the strawberries into a container with 3 tbsp (37.5 g) of granulated sugar.
Use a spoon to stir the sugar in with the strawberries, and keep mixing until the strawberries are evenly coated with the sugar.
The sugar will soften and sweeten the strawberries during the maceration process and will create a syrup out of the juices pulled from the strawberries.
Freshen the strawberry mixture with 1 tsp (2 g) of orange or lemon zest for added flavor.
Seal the container with its lid and refrigerate it for at least 30 minutes.
The longer the strawberries macerate, the more juice and syrup will develop.
Just avoid macerating the strawberries longer than 2 hours as the fruit will begin to break down.
Prepare the strawberries before mixing the rest of the shortcake to give them enough time to soak.
Mixing the Cake Batter Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) before you begin making the batter.
Remove any pans or baking sheets that you have in the oven before preheating it.
Space the oven racks evenly within your oven, so you have room to place the 3 cake pans in it.
Mix together all of the dry ingredients in a medium-sized bowl.
Start by adding 2 cups (240 g) all-purpose flour into the bowl.
Then, stir in 2 tsp (8 g) baking powder and 1/2 tsp (2.6 g) salt.
Continue mixing the dry ingredients until they are completely blended.
To remove the lumps quickly, pour the ingredients through a sifter over the bowl.
Microwave 4 tbsp (56.72 g) of unsalted butter for 15 seconds to soften it.
Place the butter in a microwave-safe container.
Rest a lid on top of the container so it is cracked.
This will keep pressure from building up in the container and allow the mixture to ventilate.
Instead of microwaving the butter to soften it, you can also leave it out at room temperature for 30 minutes.
Use a hand mixer to cream the butter and sugar together in a bowl.
Add 1 2/3 cups (333.3 g) granulated sugar into the large mixing bowl first.
Then, use a rubber spatula to scrape the softened butter on top of the sugar.
Slowly cream the two ingredients for about 30 seconds or until they form a yellow-white paste.
If you do not have a hand mixer, you can use a standing mixer instead.
Add the vanilla extract, eggs, and milk to the creamed butter and sugar.
Beat 1 US tbsp (15 mL) vanilla extract and 4 large eggs into the mixture first.
This will help add air into the eggs and make your cake light and fluffy.
Then, slowly pour in 1 cup (240 mL) of whole or 2% milk, and beat the mixture together until it is blended.
For added flavor, you can also add in ⁄2  tsp (2.5 mL) of almond extract to the mixture as well.
Use a rubber spatula to fold the dry ingredients into the wet mixture.
Continue mixing until most of the dry ingredients are moistened.
Don't worry about blending the mixture completely because you will use the hand mixer to smooth the batter.
This will prevent the dry ingredients from puffing upwards when you smooth the batter with the hand mixer or standing mixer.
Finish blending the batter until it is smooth using your hand mixer.
Begin mixing it on the slowest speed, and then increase it to a medium speed to remove any lumps from the batter.
Continue beating the batter until it is smooth.
If the batter seems dry or crumbly, add 1  tsp (4.9 mL) of milk to moisten it.
If the batter seems too wet or soupy, add 1 tsp (3.3 g) all-purpose flour to thicken it.
Cooking and Cooling the Cake Layers Put parchment paper on the bottom of 3 round 8 in (20 cm) cake pans.
The parchment paper will make it easier to slide the thin cake layers out of the pan and will prevent the cake from sticking.
The circles of parchment paper do not have to be perfectly round along the bottom but should cover the majority of the inside of the pan.
Trace the circumference of the pan onto the parchment paper and cut it out with clean scissors or kitchen scissors to create a circle that will easily line the bottom of the pan.
Spray the inside of the pan with nonstick spray for extra protection.
Pay special attention to the sides of the pan, as the cake will most likely stick to those instead of the lined bottom.
You can also spray the pan before adding the parchment paper, and then spray the inside of the pan again to help keep the parchment paper in place when you pour the batter.
Spread 2 cups (470 mL) of the batter evenly into each of the pans.
Use an offset spatula to push the batter until it covers the entire bottom of the pan.
If the batter is not spread evenly, it may burn in thinner spots or be raw in thicker spots.
Each cake pan should be filled with the same amount of batter so that all 3 layers will cook evenly.
When cooked, the layers will be approximately 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) thick.
Bake the cake layers at 350 °F (177 °C) for 14-18 minutes.
Distribute the 3 cake pans as needed to fit them into your oven.
All 3 pans will most likely not fit on the middle rack so you will need to rotate the pans halfway through the baking time.
This will ensure that all of the cakes cook and do not burn.
When done, the tops of the cakes will be a golden color, and the centers will not be gooey if you test the center with a toothpick.
Use potholders to remove the pans from the oven and place them on a rack.
Allow the cakes to cool for at least 30 minutes before removing them from the cake pans to cool the rest of the way.
Once removed, let the cakes rest for at least 1 hour until the top and bottom of the cakes are cool to the touch.
If you are having problems removing the cakes from the pans, use a knife or spatula to loosen the edges of the cake.
Assembling the Shortcake Whip heavy cream, sugar, and vanilla extract in a bowl for 1-2 minutes.
Add 1 and ⁄2 cup (240 and 120 mL) of heavy cream to the bowl first.
Then, sprinkle in 3 tbsp (37.5 g) of granulated sugar and 1 and ⁄2  tsp (4.9 and 2.5 mL) vanilla extract.
Use a hand mixer or a standing mixer on a medium-high speed to whip the ingredients together.
Continue to whip the mixture until it becomes fluffy and creates soft peaks.
For added flavor, add in 1 tsp (5 g) of lemon zest before whipping the mixture together.
You can also make a thicker whipped cream by adding in 8 ounces (240 g) of cream cheese to the mixture before whipping.
This is a fun twist on the traditional whipped topping and provides extra mouthfeel in each bite.
Rest 1 cake layer on a serving plate you can easily transport.
Choose a sturdy serving plate that will withstand the weight of the layered cake once it is assembled.
A serving plate with a slight well to it will also help to contain the juices from the macerated strawberries.
Add a layer of whipped cream and 1 cup (240 mL) of macerated strawberries.
Spread the layer of whipped cream thin so it does not pool out the sides when topped with a second cake layer.
Then, carefully distribute the macerated strawberries on top without disturbing the layer of whipped cream.
Don't worry if some of the juice from the strawberries runs down the sides of the cake.
It will add to the presentation of the dessert and the cake will soak up the juices.
Place the second cake layer, carefully, on top of the first.
Lower the second cake layer as close to the first as possible to avoid disturbing the fillings.
If it helps, lift the second layer with a spatula, and push it off the spatula with your fingers and onto the bottom layer.
Repeat the filling process for the second and third cake layer.
Garnish the cake with whipped cream, strawberries, or powdered sugar.
Frost the outside of the cake with leftover whipped cream or leave the layers exposed to show off your hard work.
Then, arrange whole strawberries along the top of the cake and sprinkle them with powdered sugar.
Serve the cake immediately or allow it to firm up in the refrigerator for 10-15 minutes.
Store any leftovers in a sealed container in the refrigerator for 5-7 days.
Just be aware that the whipped cream may begin to separate after a day or so and become watery.
Finished.
tyn_section: Hand mixer or a standing mixer
